Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 12:34PM margiejune wrote: I totally understand being scared about all this.  I was diagnosed five and a half years ago.  I was 69 at the time...pretty old, considering.  I also had DCIS and IDC.  I chose to have a lumpectomy,  chemo,  and radiation.  I did very well and have continued to do well.  I took Zoloft to lessen the panic attacks.  I have my own business and I believe that keeping my mind on that has been the key to keeping me from just melting into the ground.  I am currently taking arimidex and will be finished in September.  This site has been so important to me, in spite of the fact that I rarely post (usually just read).  I laugh and cry at all the stories...the hurts,  the victories,  the sillies,  whatever.  I don't like to "expose" my deepest feelings to those around me and this site is the perfect place to let it all hang out.  People here understand.   Those of you just beginning this journey can count on our prayers and our thoughts for your well-being.  It won't be easy,  but there is a light at the end of the tunnel! Margie
Posts.Title: Kinda scared.... MamaLambNC margiejune

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2007 10:49PM margiejune wrote: I also had benign positional vertigo at one time and it is the pits!  I couldn't turn my head with the world spinning.  Couldn't drive.  I finally, after about 2 months,  saw an ear specialist that did some of the weird things Karen talked about...such as pouring hot and cold water in my ear.  This was before bc and chemo.  There is a lot of info on the internet about this. Good luck, Margie
Posts.Title: Holy crap -- vertigo.... kimmytoo kimf

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2007 04:25PM margiejune wrote: I agree with the other ladies. It just isn't done like that any more. It certainly makes me question your surgeon's knowledge of the latest and best methods. I worked for a pathologist during the 50's, 60's, and 70's and doing frozen sections was the norm. But no more. Please get a 2nd opinion from a breast center. They need to KNOW about your cancer before making such decisions and you need a complete path report. Just my 2 cents, too.
Posts.Title: not diagnosed but worried hopingforthebest ceegra

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 05:27PM margiejune wrote: Hi!  Just want to reassure you that all of us have been where you are now and we have managed to get through it and on the other side!  Stay connected with us here and let us support you and hold your hand.  My son is military and I have a soft spot for military wives...you have a lot on your plate with frequent moves and deployments.  Give those fur-babies some extra snuggles!  Hugs to you,  along with prayers! Margie
